claim: Born in Bethlehem
notes: Cited by chief priests/scribes to Herod; widely recognized messianic expectation; Luke narrates Joseph and Mary traveling to Bethlehem where Jesus is born.
tooltip: Born in Bethlehem — Micah 5:2
summary: Born in Bethlehem

claim: Virgin conceives and bears a son called Immanuel
notes: Christians read this as fulfilled in Jesus' birth; debated in Jewish interpretation.
tooltip: Virgin conceives and bears a son called Immanuel — Isaiah 7:14
summary: Virgin conceives and bears a son called Immanuel

claim: Messiah from Davidic line with everlasting throne
notes: Davidic covenant applied to Christ.
tooltip: Messiah from Davidic line with everlasting throne — 2 Samuel 7:12-16
summary: Messiah from Davidic line with everlasting throne

claim: A forerunner prepares the way
notes: Applied to John the Baptist.
tooltip: A forerunner prepares the way — Isaiah 40:3; Malachi 3:1
summary: A forerunner prepares the way

claim: Ministry brings light to Galilee
notes: Jesus begins ministry around Capernaum.
tooltip: Ministry brings light to Galilee — Isaiah 9:1-2
summary: Ministry brings light to Galilee

claim: Anointed to proclaim good news, liberty; year of the Lord
notes: Jesus reads and applies this to himself in Nazareth.
tooltip: Anointed to proclaim good news, liberty; year of the Lord — Isaiah 61:1-2
summary: Anointed to proclaim good news, liberty; year of the Lord

claim: He heals the blind, deaf, lame
notes: Jesus cites these signs to John’s disciples (see also Luke 7:22).
tooltip: He heals the blind, deaf, lame — Isaiah 35:5-6
summary: He heals the blind, deaf, lame

claim: Speaks in parables
notes: Matthew cites fulfillment formula.
tooltip: Speaks in parables — Psalm 78:2
summary: Speaks in parables

claim: Zeal for God's house
notes: Applied to temple action and Christ’s reproach-bearing.
tooltip: Zeal for God's house — Psalm 69:9
summary: Zeal for God's house

claim: Entry to Zion humble and on a donkey
notes: Triumphal entry.
tooltip: Entry to Zion humble and on a donkey — Zechariah 9:9
summary: Entry to Zion humble and on a donkey

claim: Betrayed by a close friend
notes: Jesus cites this at the Last Supper.
tooltip: Betrayed by a close friend — Psalm 41:9
summary: Betrayed by a close friend

claim: Betrayed for thirty silver pieces
notes: Matthew references Jeremiah in a composite citation.
tooltip: Betrayed for thirty silver pieces; money ends up with the potter — Zechariah 11:12-13
summary: Betrayed for thirty silver pieces; money ends up with the potter

claim: Shepherd struck; sheep scattered
notes: Jesus quotes this about the disciples fleeing.
tooltip: Shepherd struck; sheep scattered — Zechariah 13:7
summary: Shepherd struck; sheep scattered

claim: Silent before accusers
notes: Ethiopian eunuch passage connects Isa 53 to Jesus.
tooltip: Silent before accusers — Isaiah 53:7
summary: Silent before accusers

claim: Despised, rejected; bore our sins
notes: New Testament explicitly applies Isa 53 to Jesus’ suffering.
tooltip: Despised, rejected; bore our sins — Isaiah 53:3-6
summary: Despised, rejected; bore our sins

claim: Pierced; hands/feet, mocked
notes: Casting lots for garments (v18) directly cited.
tooltip: Pierced; hands/feet, mocked — Psalm 22:16-18
summary: Pierced; hands/feet, mocked

claim: Given gall/vinegar
notes: John notes 'to fulfill the Scripture' (I thirst).
tooltip: Given gall/vinegar — Psalm 69:21
summary: Given gall/vinegar

claim: None of his bones broken
notes: John cites fulfillment at crucifixion.
tooltip: None of his bones broken — Exodus 12:46; Psalm 34:20
summary: None of his bones broken

claim: They will look on him whom they pierced
notes: John cites as fulfilled in piercing.
tooltip: They will look on him whom they pierced — Zechariah 12:10
summary: They will look on him whom they pierced

claim: Buried with the rich
notes: Joseph of Arimathea's tomb.
tooltip: Buried with the rich — Isaiah 53:9
summary: Buried with the rich

claim: Not abandoned to Sheol / Holy One not see decay
notes: Peter and Paul preach this as resurrection prophecy.
tooltip: Not abandoned to Sheol / Holy One not see decay — Psalm 16:10
summary: Not abandoned to Sheol / Holy One not see decay

claim: Ascension/exaltation to God's right hand
notes: Frequently cited enthronement text.
tooltip: Ascension/exaltation to God's right hand — Psalm 110:1
summary: Ascension/exaltation to God's right hand

claim: Priest forever after the order of Melchizedek
notes: Major Christological argument in Hebrews.
tooltip: Priest forever after the order of Melchizedek — Psalm 110:4
summary: Priest forever after the order of Melchizedek

claim: A new covenant with God's people
notes: Institution of the Eucharist; Hebrews quotes extensively.
tooltip: A new covenant with God's people — Jeremiah 31:31-34
summary: A new covenant with God's people

claim: Light to the nations (Gentiles)
notes: Simeon’s Nunc Dimittis; Paul’s mission.
tooltip: Light to the nations (Gentiles) — Isaiah 42:6; Isaiah 49:6
summary: Light to the nations (Gentiles)

claim: A stumbling stone / precious cornerstone
notes: Cornerstone motif applied to Jesus.
tooltip: A stumbling stone / precious cornerstone — Isaiah 8:14; Isaiah 28:16; Psalm 118:22
summary: A stumbling stone / precious cornerstone

claim: Out of Egypt I called my son
notes: Typological fulfillment in the Holy Family’s return.
tooltip: Out of Egypt I called my son — Hosea 11:1
summary: Out of Egypt I called my son

claim: Rachel weeping for her children
notes: Applied to Herod’s massacre.
tooltip: Rachel weeping for her children — Jeremiah 31:15
summary: Rachel weeping for her children

claim: Called a Nazarene / branch
notes: Matthew summarizes prophetic theme; not a single verse quotation.
tooltip: Called a Nazarene / branch — Isaiah 11:1 (netzer, 'branch')
summary: Called a Nazarene / branch

claim: Ministry marked by meekness and justice to the nations
notes: Matthew quotes the Servant Song.
tooltip: Ministry marked by meekness and justice to the nations — Isaiah 42:1-4
summary: Ministry marked by meekness and justice to the nations

claim: Chosen and beloved Son
notes: Baptism/Transfiguration theophany echoes.
tooltip: Chosen and beloved Son — Psalm 2:7; Isaiah 42:1
summary: Chosen and beloved Son

claim: Ministry characterized by miracles and compassion
notes: Matthew cites this as fulfilled in healings.
tooltip: Ministry characterized by miracles and compassion — Isaiah 53:4
summary: Ministry characterized by miracles and compassion

claim: Messenger of the covenant comes to the temple
notes: Composite with Isa 40:3; applied to John/Jesus arrival.
tooltip: Messenger of the covenant comes to the temple — Malachi 3:1
summary: Messenger of the covenant comes to the temple

claim: Shepherds feed on his betrayal wages (potter’s field)
notes: Purchase of the potter’s field.
tooltip: Shepherds feed on his betrayal wages (potter’s field) — Zechariah 11:13 (and Jeremiah themes)
summary: Shepherds feed on his betrayal wages (potter’s field)

claim: Hated without cause
notes: Jesus cites 'law' referring to Psalms.
tooltip: Hated without cause — Psalm 35:19; Psalm 69:4
summary: Hated without cause

claim: Mocked and reproached
notes: Passersby quote similar taunts.
tooltip: Mocked and reproached — Psalm 22:7-8
summary: Mocked and reproached

claim: Given lots for garments
notes: Explicit fulfillment citation in John.
tooltip: Given lots for garments — Psalm 22:18
summary: Given lots for garments

claim: Numbered with transgressors
notes: Jesus quotes Isa 53:12 of himself.
tooltip: Numbered with transgressors — Isaiah 53:12
summary: Numbered with transgressors

claim: Friends stand afar off
notes: Narrative alignment.
tooltip: Friends stand afar off — Psalm 38:11; Psalm 88:8
summary: Friends stand afar off

claim: Lots cast for clothing; soldiers divide garments
notes: Duplicate theme; included for distinct NT citation.
tooltip: Lots cast for clothing; soldiers divide garments — Psalm 22:18
summary: Lots cast for clothing; soldiers divide garments

claim: Thirst on the cross ('I am thirsty')
notes: John signals fulfillment.
tooltip: Thirst on the cross ('I am thirsty') — Psalm 22:15; Psalm 69:21
summary: Thirst on the cross ('I am thirsty')

claim: Casting lots for a single tunic
notes: Seamless tunic emphasized.
tooltip: Casting lots for a single tunic — Psalm 22:18
summary: Casting lots for a single tunic

claim: The stone the builders rejected becomes the cornerstone
notes: Applied to Jesus’ rejection/exaltation.
tooltip: The stone the builders rejected becomes the cornerstone — Psalm 118:22-23
summary: The stone the builders rejected becomes the cornerstone

claim: A prophet like Moses
notes: Peter applies this to Jesus.
tooltip: A prophet like Moses — Deuteronomy 18:15-19
summary: A prophet like Moses

claim: Entry accompanied by 'Hosanna' from Psalm 118
notes: Crowd acclamation from Hallel psalm.
tooltip: Entry accompanied by 'Hosanna' from Psalm 118 — Psalm 118:25-26
summary: Entry accompanied by 'Hosanna' from Psalm 118

claim: Passover Lamb points to Christ’s sacrifice
summary: Blood on doorposts spares Israel’s firstborn; prefigures Christ’s redeeming blood.
notes: The unblemished lamb’s blood applied for deliverance mirrors Jesus’ sacrificial death at Passover.
tooltip: Passover Lamb — Exodus 12

claim: Bronze Serpent lifted up foreshadows the Cross
summary: Looking upon the serpent brought life; faith in the lifted-up Son brings eternal life.
notes: Jesus explicitly identifies the serpent raised in the wilderness as a type of His crucifixion.
tooltip: Bronze Serpent — Numbers 21

claim: Scapegoat bears the sins of the people
summary: One goat slain, the other sent away — sin removed from the camp.
notes: Day of Atonement prefigures Christ’s substitutionary sacrifice and removal of sin.
tooltip: Scapegoat — Leviticus 16

claim: Noah’s Ark symbolizes salvation through Christ
summary: God preserves a remnant through judgment waters; baptism now fulfills this pattern.
notes: Peter explicitly connects the floodwaters to baptism and salvation through Christ.
tooltip: Noah’s Ark — Genesis 6–9

claim: Jonah’s three days prefigure Jesus’ burial and resurrection
summary: Jonah’s deliverance from the fish anticipates the Son of Man’s rising on the third day.
notes: Jesus cites Jonah as a sign of His own death and resurrection; see the parallel account in Luke 11:29-32 and the later reference in Matthew 16:4.
tooltip: Jonah — Matthew 12:39-41; Luke 11:29-32

claim: Joseph’s descent and exaltation foreshadow Christ’s story
summary: Rejected and sold, then exalted to save many — a clear parallel to Christ’s redemptive arc.
notes: Joseph’s humiliation and later exaltation mirror Christ’s pattern of suffering and glory.
tooltip: Joseph — Genesis 37–50

claim: Jacob’s ladder fulfilled in the Son of Man
summary: Heaven and earth joined through Christ, the living connection to God.
notes: Jesus identifies Himself as the link between God and humanity seen in Jacob’s vision.
tooltip: Jacob’s Ladder — Genesis 28

claim: Manna from heaven points to the Bread of Life
summary: Israel fed in the wilderness; Christ offers true spiritual nourishment.
notes: Jesus contrasts perishable manna with Himself, the living bread from heaven.
tooltip: Manna — Exodus 16

claim: Water from the rock symbolizes Christ’s Spirit
summary: God provides life-giving water; Christ gives living water to all who thirst.
notes: Paul and John connect the rock and its water to Christ’s spiritual provision.
tooltip: Water from the Rock — Exodus 17

claim: Melchizedek prefigures Christ’s eternal priesthood
summary: Priest-king of righteousness and peace — without beginning or end.
notes: Hebrews develops Melchizedek as the prototype for Christ’s superior priesthood.
tooltip: Melchizedek — Genesis 14; Psalm 110

claim: David’s throne anticipates Christ’s everlasting reign
summary: The covenant with David finds ultimate fulfillment in the Messiah’s eternal kingdom.
notes: God’s promise to establish David’s line forever culminates in Jesus’ kingship.
tooltip: Davidic Covenant — 2 Samuel 7

claim: Messiah comes before the Temple’s destruction
summary: Daniel’s seventy weeks place the Anointed One before the city and sanctuary are destroyed.
notes: Many Christian interpreters read Daniel 9’s ‘anointed one’/‘cut off’ as pointing to the Messiah’s arrival and death prior to the destruction of Jerusalem and the temple in 70 AD (cf. Jesus’ explicit predictions of the temple’s ruin). Views vary on the exact chronology and symbolism. Some Second Temple Jewish interpretations at Qumran (Dead Sea Scrolls) also engage Danielic chronologies and messianic timetables—for example, 11QMelchizedek (11Q13) and related pesharim anticipate an anointed deliverer and imminent end-time vindication.
tooltip: Messiah before the Temple’s destruction — Daniel 9:24-27

claim: Son of Man given everlasting dominion
summary: The one like a son of man comes with the clouds and receives an everlasting kingdom from the Ancient of Days.
notes: Daniel’s ‘one like a son of man’ is a central OT backdrop for Jesus’ self-designation ‘Son of Man’ and his claims about coming with the clouds and being enthroned; echoed at Jesus’ trial, in the Olivet Discourse, Stephen’s vision, and Revelation.
tooltip: Son of Man given dominion — Daniel 7:13–14

claim: Akedah (Isaac) foreshadows the Father’s sacrifice of the Son
summary: Abraham offers his beloved son; on the third day God provides the ram — a pattern fulfilled in Christ’s cross.
notes: The binding of Isaac prefigures the gospel: the beloved ‘only’ son, wood for the offering carried by the son, the ‘third day’ motif (Gen 22:4), and God Himself providing the lamb (Gen 22:8). NT authors reflect on this as a figure of resurrection (Heb 11:19) and divine self-giving (Rom 8:32); James highlights Abraham’s obedient faith (Jas 2:21–23).
tooltip: Akedah (Isaac) — Genesis 22
